issues.title: Missing Commercial Speech Constitutional Protections
issues.description: The policy lacks acknowledgment that commercial speech receives First Amendment protection and that content-based restrictions must be reasonable and viewpoint-neutral. This is required when districts regulate commercial advertising and promotional materials.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of a school district may initiate and carry on any program, activity, or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with, or preempted by, any law and which is not in conflict with the purposes for which school districts are established.

issues.required_language: The district recognizes that commercial speech receives constitutional protection and that any content-based restrictions on advertising and promotional materials must be reasonable, viewpoint-neutral, and serve legitimate educational interests.

issues.title: Missing Appeal Process for Denied Materials
issues.description: California law requires districts to provide due process when restricting speech or promotional materials. The policy lacks any appeal mechanism for organizations whose materials are rejected.

legal_citations.text: Students of the public schools shall have the right to exercise freedom of speech and of the press... subject to reasonable time, place, and manner restrictions.

issues.required_language: Organizations whose promotional materials are denied may appeal the decision to the Superintendent within 10 business days. The Superintendent's decision may be appealed to the Board of Trustees within 10 business days of the Superintendent's decision.

issues.title: Insufficient Public Forum Analysis
issues.description: The policy does not clearly define what type of forum (if any) the district's communication channels represent, which is necessary to determine the appropriate level of First Amendment protection and permissible restrictions.

legal_citations.text: It is the intent of the Legislature that school districts not restrict the use of school facilities for specified purposes based on religious, political, or other discriminatory reasons.

issues.required_language: District communication channels for promotional materials constitute a limited public forum. Restrictions must be reasonable in light of the purpose served by the forum and must be applied in a viewpoint-neutral manner.

issues.title: Missing Specific Timeline for Material Review
issues.description: While the policy requires submission "at least two weeks prior to distribution," it does not specify how long the district has to review and respond to requests, which could create due process concerns.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of a school district may initiate and carry on any program, activity, or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with, or preempted by, any law.

issues.required_language: The Superintendent or designee shall review submitted materials and provide a written decision within 5 business days of receipt. If materials are denied, the decision shall include specific reasons for denial.

issues.title: Incomplete Fee Structure Documentation
issues.description: The policy references promotional fees "as described in AR 1325" but the regulation only mentions a $250 banner fee. A complete fee schedule should be documented for transparency and consistency.

legal_citations.text: The governing board of any school district may charge a fee, not to exceed the cost of providing the service, for any service rendered by the district which is not required to be provided as part of the minimum school program.

issues.required_language: Fee Schedule for Promotional Materials: Banner placement - $250 per school site; Electronic distribution of flyers - $X per distribution; Other promotional services - fees not to exceed actual costs of providing the service.
